**Bastille** (stylised as **BΔSTILLE**) are a British [rock](/wiki/Rock_music
"Rock music") band formed in 2010. The group began as a solo project by lead
vocalist [Dan Smith](/wiki/Dan_Smith_\(singer\) "Dan Smith \(singer\)"), but
later expanded to include keyboardist Kyle Simmons, bassist and guitarist Will
Farquarson, and drummer Chris Wood.[1] The name of the band derives from
[Bastille Day](/wiki/Bastille_Day "Bastille Day"), which is celebrated on 14
July, the date of Smith's birthday.[2]

After an independently released debut single and a self-released EP, the band
signed to [Virgin Records](/wiki/Virgin_Records "Virgin Records").[3] Their
first studio album, _[Bad Blood](/wiki/Bad_Blood_\(Bastille_album\) "Bad Blood
\(Bastille album\)")_ , was released in March 2013 and entered the [UK Albums
Chart](/wiki/UK_Albums_Chart "UK Albums Chart") at number one.[4] The band was
nominated for four [Brit Awards](/wiki/Brit_Awards "Brit Awards") at the [2014
ceremony](/wiki/2014_Brit_Awards "2014 Brit Awards"), winning the [British
Breakthrough Act](/wiki/British_Breakthrough_Act "British Breakthrough
Act").[5] As of November 2014, Bastille have sold over five million records in
the US and 2.5 million records in the UK.[6]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bastille_\(band\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Formation and early
releases[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bastille_\(band\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Formation and early releases")]

Bastille debuted in July 2010 with their limited edition 7" single that
featured the two tracks "Flaws" and "Icarus". Released through London-based
independent record label Young & Lost Club, only 300 copies were pressed.[7]
One of the copies found its way into the hands of Alex Baker, presenter of the
unsigned/independent artists radio show on Kerrang! Radio. Baker started to
support Bastille on air, and the band began to find an audience. They released
the EP _[Laura Palmer](/wiki/Laura_Palmer_EP "Laura Palmer EP")_ themselves
later in 2011.[8] After debuting further tracks online through sites such as
YouTube and MySpace, the band's audience started to grow.[9] In December 2011
Smith signed a contract with Virgin Records.[3] The group subsequently secured
a few support slots and later performed at major UK festivals including
[Glastonbury](/wiki/Glastonbury_Festival "Glastonbury Festival"), the [Isle of
Wight](/wiki/Isle_of_Wight_Festival "Isle of Wight Festival"),
[Redfest](/wiki/Redfest "Redfest") Reading and Leeds Festival and
[Blissfields](/wiki/Blissfields "Blissfields"). The band also recorded and
released two parts of their mix-tape titled _Other People 's Heartache_ for
free.[9]

### _Bad Blood_ and _All This Bad Blood_
(2012–15)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bastille_\(band\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Bad Blood and All This Bad Blood \(2012–15\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Bastille_at_Queens%27_College_May_Ball_2013.JPG/220px-
Bastille_at_Queens%27_College_May_Ball_2013.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bastille_at_Queens%27_College_May_Ball_2013.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bastille_at_Queens%27_College_May_Ball_2013.JPG "Enlarge")

Bastille in concert at [Queens' College](/wiki/Queens%27_College,_Cambridge
"Queens' College, Cambridge") [May Ball](/wiki/May_Ball "May Ball"), 2013

On 27 April 2012, their first official single release,
"[Overjoyed](/wiki/Overjoyed_\(Bastille_song\) "Overjoyed \(Bastille
song\)")", was released through [Virgin Records](/wiki/Virgin_Records "Virgin
Records"), as confirmed by EMI on 1 May 2012.[10] Following its video premiere
in November 2011, popular music publication, [_Q_
Magazine](/wiki/Q_\(magazine\) "Q \(magazine\)") introduced the track as its
'Track of the Day' for 7 March 2012.[11] The second single to be released from
the upcoming debut studio album, _[Bad
Blood](/wiki/Bad_Blood_\(Bastille_album\) "Bad Blood \(Bastille album\)")_ ,
was the eponymous track, "[Bad Blood](/wiki/Bad_Blood_\(Bastille_song\) "Bad
Blood \(Bastille song\)")". An accompanying video for the single was released
on the band's official VEVO channel on 29 June 2012, and digitally through
Virgin Records on 20 August 2012. Bastille were also named 'New Band of the
Day' by British newspaper _[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_
in July 2012.[12] The song charted moderately at number 90 in the United
Kingdom, and saw the group's first entry into the chart. In August 2012 the
band performed at UK festivals like [Reading](/wiki/Reading_Festival "Reading
Festival") and [Leeds](/wiki/Reading_Festival "Reading Festival"), as well as
supporting British singer-songwriter [Emeli Sandé](/wiki/Emeli_Sand%C3%A9
"Emeli Sandé"). They later played a small headlining tour, titled 'Flaws Tour'
in October 2012, with [Swiss Lips](/wiki/Swiss_Lips "Swiss Lips") as their
support act. in November 2012, the band performed at Hong Kong's Clockenflap
Music and Arts Festival, their first outside of Europe. Their third single, a
re-release of their first 7" non-album single "[Flaws](/wiki/Flaws_\(song\)
"Flaws \(song\)")", was a commercial success, earning the group their first
position in the UK Top 40, debuting at number-twenty-one. The song "Oblivion"
was featured in Season 4 Episode 9 of [The Vampire
Diaries](/wiki/The_Vampire_Diaries "The Vampire Diaries") in December
2012.[13]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Provinssirock_20130614_-_Bastille_-_01.jpg/220px-
Provinssirock_20130614_-_Bastille_-_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Provinssirock_20130614_-_Bastille_-_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Provinssirock_20130614_-_Bastille_-_01.jpg "Enlarge")

Dan Smith at [Provinssirock](/wiki/Provinssirock "Provinssirock") festival
2013 in [Seinäjoki](/wiki/Sein%C3%A4joki "Seinäjoki"), Finland

In February 2013, Bastille confirmed the release of the fourth single to be
taken from _Bad Blood_ , "[Pompeii](/wiki/Pompeii_\(Bastille_song\) "Pompeii
\(Bastille song\)")". The song was positively reviewed by critics, reaching
number two in the United Kingdom and number five in the US. Their debut album
_Bad Blood_ was released on 4 March 2013, and placed at number one in the [UK
Albums Chart](/wiki/UK_Albums_Chart "UK Albums Chart") . On 11 March, Bastille
were announced to be playing at Leeds and Reading Festival in August 2013.[14]
In an interview with [Digital Spy](/wiki/Digital_Spy "Digital Spy") in March
2013, "[Laura Palmer](/wiki/Laura_Palmer_\(Bastille_song\) "Laura Palmer
\(Bastille song\)")" was revealed to be the fifth single to be released from
the album, by lead vocalist, Dan Smith.[15] It was released on 3 June 2013,
and an accompanying video for the track premiered through the band's official
VEVO page on 12 April 2013.[16] The group joined English rock band
[Muse](/wiki/Muse_\(band\) "Muse \(band\)") as a supporting act on their [The
2nd Law Tour](/wiki/The_2nd_Law_Tour "The 2nd Law Tour") in May 2013 and did
so again in June 2013.[17] In May 2013, Bastille released their _Haunt_ EP in
the US via iTunes. On Saturday 6 July the band headlined their first UK summer
music festival at [Blissfields](/wiki/Blissfields "Blissfields").[18] Smith
was quoted as saying "We're massively excited about our first ever headline
slot at a festival. Particularly because we love Blissfields so much, and
because they've been so supportive to us over the last couple of years." The
performance coincided with the band appearing on the cover of a national music
publication, [Notion magazine](/wiki/Notion_magazine "Notion magazine"), for
the first time. On 24 August 2013, "[Things We Lost in the
Fire](/wiki/Things_We_Lost_in_the_Fire_\(song\) "Things We Lost in the Fire
\(song\)")" was released as the sixth single from the band's debut album.[19]
A music video for the song was shot in [Vilnius](/wiki/Vilnius "Vilnius") and
[Kėdainiai](/wiki/K%C4%97dainiai "Kėdainiai"), Lithuania.[20] On 3 September
2013, Bastille released their _Bad Blood_ album in the US via
iTunes.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

On 9 October 2013 Bastille released a new single, "[Of the
Night](/wiki/Of_the_Night "Of the Night")", a mash-up of the songs "[The
Rhythm of the Night](/wiki/The_Rhythm_of_the_Night "The Rhythm of the Night")"
by [Corona](/wiki/Corona_\(group\) "Corona \(group\)") and "[Rhythm Is a
Dancer](/wiki/Rhythm_Is_a_Dancer "Rhythm Is a Dancer")" by [Snap!](/wiki/Snap!
"Snap!"). The single debuted at number two on UK Singles Chart. The song was
promoting _[All This Bad Blood](/wiki/All_This_Bad_Blood "All This Bad
Blood")_ , a reissue of the band's debut album, released on 25 November 2013.
In January 2014 Will Farquarson said in an interview with
_[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)")_ magazine
that the band had already started to work on its second album in between tour
dates.[21] The band performed on _[Saturday Night
Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_ on 25 January 2014. On
4 February 2014 Bastille won the [BRIT Award](/wiki/BRIT_Awards "BRIT Awards")
for Best Breakthrough Act and performed a remixed version of "Pompeii" with
[Rudimental](/wiki/Rudimental "Rudimental") and their song "[Waiting All
Night](/wiki/Waiting_All_Night "Waiting All Night")" at the
[ceremony](/wiki/2014_BRIT_Awards "2014 BRIT Awards"). Two hours after their
appearance, sales of _Bad Blood_ were up by 132% to give them a second week at
number one in the UK album chart and "Pompeii" had climbed 29 places in the
singles.[22] On 1 April 2014 the Official Charts Company announced that Bad
Blood was the biggest selling digital album of 2013, and Number 11 in the
over-all Official Artist Albums Top 40 of 2013.[23] Also in April 2014, the
band performed at the [Coachella Valley Music and Arts
Festival](/wiki/Coachella_Valley_Music_and_Arts_Festival "Coachella Valley
Music and Arts Festival") at the Empire Polo Club in [Indio,
California](/wiki/Indio,_California "Indio, California"). On 31 May 2014 the
band took part in the Annual [KROQ Weenie Roast](/wiki/KROQ_Weenie_Roast "KROQ
Weenie Roast") in [Irvine, California](/wiki/Irvine,_California "Irvine,
California"), performing among other bands including [The
Neighbourhood](/wiki/The_Neighbourhood "The Neighbourhood") and [Fall Out
Boy](/wiki/Fall_Out_Boy "Fall Out Boy"). On 13 July 2014, Bastille played at
[T in the Park](/wiki/T_in_the_Park "T in the Park"). In September 2014 they
released the last single from _Bad Blood_ ,
"[Oblivion](/wiki/Oblivion_\(Bastille_song\) "Oblivion \(Bastille song\)")",
the Bad Blood Tour finished in 2015.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### _VS._ , _Wild World_
(2014–2017)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bastille_\(band\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: VS., Wild World \(2014–2017\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Bastille_2015-7.jpg/220px-
Bastille_2015-7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bastille_2015-7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bastille_2015-7.jpg "Enlarge")

Dan Smith (2015)

In late 2013 Bastille began to play new songs called "Blame" and "Campus".
Another song called "Oil On Water" was played during sound-check and leaked
online.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] They began proper work on the album in 2014,[24] and planned to
start recording it in September.[25] Farquarson said that they had "16 or 17
tracks" demoed already for the album. He also said “We’re going into the
studio in September to record; hopefully by then we’ll have 20 or maybe more.
I think it’s always better to have more material and whittle it down. Our
producer has gone on tour with us, so we’ve been doing things on our days off
and during sound-checks."[25][26] Dan Smith said the album will include more
guitars saying "we didn't really have much of that on the first album and it
may not end up on it but it would be quite interesting to try it out. We feel
quite free. If we want to go quite electronic then we can and if we want to go
more rocky and indie then we can."[26] On 21 October 2014 Bastille announced
their third mixtape, _VS. (Other People 's Heartache, Pt.III)_ with the
release of their song "Torn Apart", featuring the artist Grades and
[Lizzo](/wiki/Lizzo "Lizzo") on [Zane Lowe](/wiki/Zane_Lowe "Zane Lowe")'s BBC
Radio 1 show. They also wrote and recorded the song "The Driver" for the re-
score of the film _[Drive](/wiki/Drive_\(2011_film\) "Drive \(2011 film\)")_
which was released a week later and will also feature on the mixtape. _VS.
(Other People 's Heartache, Pt.III)_ featured the Gemma Sharples Quartet,
[Haim](/wiki/Haim_\(band\) "Haim \(band\)"), [MNEK](/wiki/MNEK "MNEK"), Tyde,
Rationale, [Lizzo](/wiki/Lizzo "Lizzo"), Grades, [Angel Haze](/wiki/Angel_Haze
"Angel Haze"), F*U*G*Z, Braque, [Rag'n'Bone Man](/wiki/Rag%27n%27Bone_Man
"Rag'n'Bone Man"), and [Skunk Anansie](/wiki/Skunk_Anansie "Skunk Anansie").
_VS. (Other People 's Heartache, Pt.III)_ was released on 8 December 2014. In
November 2014, Bastille were featured on the [Band Aid 30](/wiki/Band_Aid_30
"Band Aid 30") version of "[Do They Know It's
Christmas?](/wiki/Do_They_Know_It%27s_Christmas%3F "Do They Know It's
Christmas?")".[27] They were nominated for [Best New
Artist](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_New_Artist "Grammy Award for Best New
Artist") at the [57th Annual Grammy Awards](/wiki/57th_Annual_Grammy_Awards
"57th Annual Grammy Awards"),[28] but lost out to [Sam
Smith](/wiki/Sam_Smith_\(singer\) "Sam Smith \(singer\)").[29]

In 2015, Bastille recruited a new touring member [Charlie
Barnes](/wiki/Charlie_Barnes_\(musician\) "Charlie Barnes \(musician\)").[30]
On 22 September 2015, Bastille released an independent single called
"Hangin'". The band also featured on the _[Kill Your
Friends](/wiki/Kill_Your_Friends_\(film\) "Kill Your Friends \(film\)")_
(2015) soundtrack with a cover of the [Sugababes](/wiki/Sugababes "Sugababes")
debut single "[Overload](/wiki/Overload_\(Sugababes_song\) "Overload
\(Sugababes song\)")". It was announced via [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook
"Facebook") that their second album would be released in 2016. Also, during
that summer, the band debuted two new songs live: "Grip" and "Snakes."[31] In
April 2016, the band debuted a new song entitled "The Currents".[32] On 2 June
2016, the band uploaded a trailer including an excerpt from the then-
unreleased song _Two Evils_ announcing the name of the album to be [_Wild
World_](/wiki/Wild_World_\(album\) "Wild World \(album\)").[33] On 9 June, it
was announced that the band's new single, "Good Grief", would be released on
16 June 2016.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] On 16 June 2016, [Annie Mac](/wiki/Annie_Mac
"Annie Mac") debuted "[Good Grief](/wiki/Good_Grief_\(Bastille_song\) "Good
Grief \(Bastille song\)")" on her [BBC Radio 1](/wiki/BBC_Radio_1 "BBC Radio
1") show as the "hottest track." The track was immediately released to radio,
streaming services, and for purchase following the debut.[34] In an interview
with Mac following the song's premiere, Dan Smith revealed that their second
album would "go through a variety of sounds, but it is very much us
[Bastille]." On 24 June 2016, Bastille performed the songs "Good Grief" and
"Two Evils" live for the first time at [Glastonbury
Festival](/wiki/Glastonbury_Festival "Glastonbury Festival") as part of their
set on the Other Stage.[35] On 30 June 2016, Bastille announced that the
release of the second LP _Wild World_ and embarked on their Wild Wild World
Tour in July.[36] Released on 8 September, the album reached the top of the
mid-week sales chart,[37] while the band set up pop-up shops in London, New
York and Los Angeles to promote the release.[38] On 16 September, it was
confirmed that _Wild World_ had reached #1 on both the U.K. and Scottish album
charts.[39]

On [World Record Store Day](/wiki/Record_Store_Day "Record Store Day") 2017,
the band released an original song titled Comfort of Strangers.

In August 2017, the band released a version of the [Green Day](/wiki/Green_Day
"Green Day") song "[Basket Case](/wiki/Basket_Case_\(song\) "Basket Case
\(song\)")" for the [Peter Serafinowicz](/wiki/Peter_Serafinowicz "Peter
Serafinowicz") series _[The Tick](/wiki/The_Tick_\(2016_TV_series\) "The Tick
\(2016 TV series\)")_.[40]

The band announced their third studio album, scheduled for release in 2018.
Speaking to [NME](/wiki/NME "NME"), Smith said "We never really stop writing
and recording, but I can confirm we spent a lot of this year writing our third
album."[41]

On September 1, 2017 the band Headlined the Annual Pilton Party[42][43] Held
at Pilton Worthy Farm home of the [Glastonbury
Festival](/wiki/Glastonbury_Festival "Glastonbury Festival").

On November 23, 2017, [Craig David](/wiki/Craig_David "Craig David") and
Bastille released "[I Know You](/wiki/I_Know_You_\(Craig_David_song\) "I Know
You \(Craig David song\)"),” the second single from David’s album, _[The Time
Is Now](/wiki/The_Time_Is_Now_\(album\) "The Time Is Now \(album\)")._ The
single peaked at number 5 in 2018.[44]

On November 9, 2017, the band released a music video for “World Gone Mad”, a
song for the Netflix movie [Bright](/wiki/Bright_\(film\) "Bright
\(film\)").[45]

## Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bastille_\(band\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Media")]

Bastille's music has been used on the TV soap [Hollyoaks](/wiki/Hollyoaks
"Hollyoaks") with one week in the early summer focused on Bastille's song
"[Laura Palmer](/wiki/Laura_Palmer_\(song\) "Laura Palmer \(song\)")". Their
music also has been on: _[Made in Chelsea](/wiki/Made_in_Chelsea "Made in
Chelsea")_ and _[The Vampire
Diaries](/wiki/The_Vampire_Diaries_\(novel_series\) "The Vampire Diaries
\(novel series\)")_.[46] Bastille can also be heard on
[EastEnders](/wiki/EastEnders "EastEnders")' [autumn](/wiki/Autumn "Autumn")
(2014) trailer with "Things We Lost in the Fire". They can also be heard on
[Teen Wolf](/wiki/Teen_Wolf_\(2011_TV_series\) "Teen Wolf \(2011 TV series\)")
and on the fourth episode of _[How to Get Away with
Murder](/wiki/How_to_Get_Away_with_Murder "How to Get Away with Murder")_ with
the [Naughty Boy](/wiki/Naughty_Boy "Naughty Boy") collaboration "No One's
Here to Sleep". Their song [Pompeii](/wiki/Pompeii_\(Bastille_song\) "Pompeii
\(Bastille song\)") is featured in First Touch game, _First Touch Soccer 15_ ,
the [Konami](/wiki/Konami "Konami") game, _[Pro Evolution Soccer
2015](/wiki/Pro_Evolution_Soccer_2015 "Pro Evolution Soccer 2015")_ , and the
2014 movie, _Mr. Peabody and Sherman_. The song "Haunt" can be heard in the
season 1 finale of the TV series _[Finding Carter](/wiki/Finding_Carter
"Finding Carter")_.[47] The band's music has appeared in the [FIFA video
games](/wiki/FIFA_\(video_game_series\) "FIFA \(video game series\)") three
times: Weight of Living, Pt. II is featured in _[FIFA 13](/wiki/FIFA_13 "FIFA
13")_ , Hangin' is featured in _[FIFA 16](/wiki/FIFA_16 "FIFA 16")_ , and
[Send Them Off!](/wiki/Send_Them_Off! "Send Them Off!") is featured in _[FIFA
17](/wiki/FIFA_17 "FIFA 17")_.

## Awards and
nominations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bastille_\(band\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Awards and nominations")]

Main article: [List of awards and nominations received by
Bastille](/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Bastille "List of
awards and nominations received by Bastille")

Bastille have [won several music
awards](/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Bastille "List of
awards and nominations received by Bastille") and landed many nominations,
including ones for [Brit Awards](/wiki/Brit_Awards "Brit Awards"), [Billboard
Music Awards](/wiki/Billboard_Music_Awards "Billboard Music Awards"), [World
Music Awards](/wiki/World_Music_Awards "World Music Awards"), and [Grammy
Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Awards "Grammy Awards"). Bastille has sold over 8 million
records worldwide.[6]
